page.title: 11LANDSCAPE OF CHERINGTON
page.content: Geology, relief and drainage were the three elements of landscape considered. Our area's geology belongs to the Jurassic Era. Then, millions of years ago, in a sea covering this part of Britain, the rocks of the Cotswold area were laid down. These rocks were the Great Oolite, a white/grey limestone and Forest Marble a more shelly, creamy limestone. The relief of the area originates in the Miocene when the Cotswolds were uplifted to form an escarpment. Our area forms part of the dip slope with land falling from 170m at Hampton Fields, to the south-east at an overall gradient of 1:50. The area is cut by two valleys, one a dry valley of glacial origins to the north of Cherington. The other valley, with a stream flowing west is responsible for the area's drainage
